segments.text: How do you deal with that?
That's part of the question.
Well, you don't want to be, you're not for sale.
If you ever lose sight of that, you're dead.
But we're not for sale.
We're for rent, but we're not for sale.
But we'll decide whether or not we'll rent out or we'll retire.

learn to do something and you're going to have a talent and as long as you don't object on your own set of principles whatever they are and they differ around the world then you're willing if you're willing to do it then you can decide the terms of the contract that you will do
We are not, however, in the position of being for sale.
We just won't go out and do anything as long as you pay us.
And how do you afford that?
Is that 20%?
That's right.
If one administration comes in and we've got some turkey who's got the wrong philosophy, and it's wrong, why?
Because it doesn't agree with me.
That's my responsibility, and I've got to be prepared to take that risk of defending what I believe is right.
That is, not only, you know, so one of our whole divisions finds its resources may be wiped out.
And I'm looking.
The contract is terminated.
The resources are not coming in.
Is that a statement that that's the end of the deed for that research?
No.
Now we're back to one of your other questions.
Maybe.
Maybe not.
Got analogies.
Who are the other clients?

whose lives in our society, and I'm personifying here again, take lives as meaning not only individuals, but industries, institutions, foundations, those people that we interact with and what we do has an impact on them.
I've got to go to those people, my job, and not just take
the President of the United States work for it, just because he thinks that defense is great.
And get everybody I've got in this organization working on defense and completely abandon human baggage.
I may not be willing to do that.
I might do that, but I might not.
But how am I going to decide that?
I'm going to go talk to all sources of information
first of all, that I have access to, that I can get to, whose opinion I respect, and whose lives are influenced by that particular area that has a problem.
And I've got to decide, based upon that input, and I've drawn the resources of my colleagues in this system, in the UT system, in the California system,
the industries, the entities, those lives that that particular area otherwise would have been impacted.
But equally as importantly, maybe more importantly, I sit down with those people and ask them, what happened?
And why?
And what does the future hold?
And if we ride through this downtick together, how do we come out of it?
And who cares?
And if so, so what?
Then I'll make a decision.
But if I didn't have that 20%, we could go through all of that and decide they ought to survive.
And if the productivity wasn't there to fund it,
You just cry and say, I'm sorry, I'd like to back you, but I can't.
And no, you die.
Or you'd have to be for sale, and then you'd have to make that choice.
I'd probably die.
It's my thing, too.
Go back to TI.
Well, I was on a higher philosophical plane at that time with that comment.
I might go to the mountains and get my fly rod out and fish.
There are other alternatives.
But TEAS has that responsibility.
It's been given that responsibility.
It's been given that trust, and it's been given that authority.
So is it that 20% of the lives you have the flexibility to take those first risks and ride out the storm?
That's right.
It's the key.
and see if you spent all that 20% fully funding all these programs.
You'd be dead.
You'd sold yourself.
You'd sold your option, your flexibility.
Everybody has got to carry it.
You see, this agency works much differently than the factories across the way and the agri-trail stations.
They're on the inverse.
They're 80%.
Just now moving to something like 20% of outside generated research, the money they get from the legislature, the Texas legislature, is more like 80% of their budget.
I have a question that I've asked everyone I've interviewed.
Oh good, this is the loaded question.
Well, this is a more general question in a sense, but I keep hearing the term high-tech, and I don't understand the difference between high-tech and tech technologies.
I don't either.
And frankly, I don't think anybody does.
It's a buzzword like basic and applied research.
I hold the philosophy that nobody's smart enough to define that either.
I think that we can conceptualize the difference between research and development.
I think I can define for you where research stops and development continues.
I cannot define for you where basic research stops and applied research continues.
Or how you can say when you go into a research project, which one it is.
Or when you come out of it.
I can get to kind of glib about it.
Glib's the wrong word.
I can't think of the right one I'd want to use.
That's close enough.
It's in the ballpark.
almost tongue-in-cheek, maybe sarcastic even.
I like von Braun's definition of basic research.
It's the research I'm doing when I don't know what I'm doing.
Another definition that I think fits rather well in that same category is
Basic research is done under a grant and applied research is done under a contract.
Or one that goes a little bit further in the same mode is if anybody's willing to pay for it, it's applied.
Basic research is the research that's not funded.
Another one.
At any time, see?
Then what do you say how much?
So you've got to take it to the extreme.
As soon as somebody's willing to pay you to do that research, it's applied.
Because you know they've got a profit motive.
You know there's sinister reasons.
You know you're for sale and you sold your purity, academic soul, to get this thing done.
I think it's unmitigated.
philosophical mishmash to try to even define it.
I think we damage ourselves greatly in the academic community in attempting.
But some people have the concept that basic research is the research that scientists do, and applied research is the research that engineers do.
Well, I have the disadvantage, probably, of having been educated as a scientist.
Why is that a disadvantage?
And mutated into an engineer.
So I've done research.
I've taught in math and physics.
I've done research.
So what's the difference between a scientist and an engineer?
There is a difference.
I became an engineer because I was interested in the applications of the fundamental laws of nature.
But when I became an engineer, I did not give up being a scientist.
And when I was a scientist, and functioning as a scientist, I think I have the capability of putting on either hat effectively.
I've got enough confidence in myself to say that.
I believe I can walk into the classroom and share with my fellow mankind some knowledge about how Mother Nature drives this planet.
And I can do that reasonably effectively in what we call the discipline of physics, the laws of physical science.
I think I can walk into an electronics engineering class and share the principles of applying those laws to make an integrated circuit function in a computer to do calculations.
Those two relate that way.
But when I have all my business had and I'm in the laboratory,
looking for the maybe Porter's Law.
I used to search for that a lot when I was a sophomore.
Or at least I would search for it.
I just thought it would happen.
But if I'm looking for the absorption coefficient of sound in liquid nitrogen, and to see how it might vary as a function of temperature or pressure or something,
And that's really all I'm interested in.
I wonder how Mother Nature controls that.
How does the sound move through the production?
How does it change and how does it soar?
I learned early on that if I pay attention and think freely, that I might discover an acoustic device for detecting an arrhythmia
in your heart, which I would call, I believe we can create an industry and sell a product.
And as soon as I have that piece of data that has application, what's I doing?
What I say is, I was a scientist doing research.
And the results turn out to be to have an application.
The fallacy now injects a piece of personal philosophy in the larger scheme of higher education.
The thing I don't like, the thing I'm worried about personally in our nation, is that to try to create a self-image
We want to demand to know what the result is going to be rather than taking the risk to be a free thinker and just use your intellect and take advantage of where the research.
Most people don't even understand that word.
You can't research until you've searched.
What are you doing?
You're searching.
And if you think you've found something,
Before you publish it, before you go share it, you better re-search it to be sure it's reproducible.
Otherwise, you're going to find yourself rather embarrassed.
And we see our colleagues from time to time around this country announcing great breakthroughs because they observed it one time and they only searched it.
They didn't research it.
I find an attitude among some academicians that if anything has value or makes money,
or has application into our society, the free enterprise, profit-driven, capitalistic, wonderful America, that they violated their role as an academician, if they shouldn't be involved.
Well, that's part of the unmeditated stuff I think is unnecessary and not healthy to the strength of the country and the society that we're in.
Many times, though, when I had my engineering handle,
What I was trying to develop based upon research that had already been done.
Now it was in the department, which I can define differently.
I was trying to build a machine that would take advantage of those principles that were based upon good research.
But I was trying to develop a machine that would build in a great circuit.
And while I was doing that development, I got a glimmer.
Where am I engineering at?
Doing development to make money for Texas Instruments by building integrated circuits.
Matter of fact, we were building the first computer to go on board the F-111 so our pilots could fly in and mock whatever about 100 feet off the ground and about run into a building.
It occurred, I made some measurements that led me to believe that I could now design and set up experiments in a research model.
Moving back now into, I don't know what the entry is, I can't go into the development of it, I'm not sure that that's going to be true.
that led me to define my PhD dissertation.
To come back and answer very fundamental questions about Mother Nature's principles that would help us to understand how deeply it is produced.
And we knew that it was produced, but we didn't know why or how.
We didn't understand the laws.
And that's what I ended up doing.
But I was wearing an engineering hat, too.
So that's kind of the end of my soapbox.
I have an example or two of why I think it's found that way.
You have the problem of, it's encountered in research and all this big time.
I'm sure you've had it for a long time, just in the short term.
Well, that's just a reality.
You just do what is the best you can.
Sure, absolutely.
If you end up deciding to go on a project where the sponsor has got the short-term deal and you end up getting caught,
you have put in jeopardy, potentially in jeopardy, the team of researchers to be cut off in the middle of what otherwise independent of the sponsor.
That's why I feel like the agency itself has to believe in the research that's being done, not because the sponsor wanted to pay for it, but because they believe it was good research to do.
So in case the sponsor decides that
they're no longer going to sponsor you.
At least you just don't yank the rug out and say, well, I signed that deal, and you slam the door.

Now, as I said earlier, this business of research is so dynamic and changes so rapidly that you may be off on fission research, and all of a sudden, somebody makes a breakthrough infusion that says, you know,
We just got through, you know, we're right in the middle of that in high energy physics right now.
It's one of the reasons the argument's being made for the super-electro-super-client.
And the Brookhaven project, after hundreds of millions of dollars, it's been shut down.
Technology's changed.
Somebody else mentioned that.
Well, or somebody, you know, you skin the cat a different way.
But you see, that's the risk.
If you want to try to accomplish something, do you do parallel projects?
Sure you do.
Should we ordain only one university research lab to work on microelectronics?
Heck no.
But yet, if you do too much of that, you spread your resources so thin.
But if everybody was doing fission, nobody would have done fission.
Yeah, that's right.
You made my point better than I did.
But are there any other points that you would like to make in terms of your views of T's history, things that you've noticed that I haven't brought up?
No, I think you brought them out well with your questions.
I don't think they've done very good job.
I would say this about the agency.
as an entity in the state and in the A&M system.
In this particular window of time, Texas and America, I think TEAS has the opportunity to play a role that's
at least as meaningful as any other part of the system to the future for the next 20 to 50 years, I would say.
I like, personally, this interdisciplinary blending of comics from otherwise very diverse disciplines.
doesn't scare me, doesn't bother me, I think it stimulates me to create in the process.
If you take a look at the sources of invention, what you find is that 99% of the time, most of the time, the idea for a new product came from somebody who had absolutely no obligation.
So, let's not lose that, particularly in the university environment, the academic environment, the research environment, where bright minds, young and old, come together, interact.
The more we cross our lines and interact with one another, the better off we are.
Personal philosophy.
Let's not be so rigid in defining the constraint.

It goes, I think, in a self-analysis, I think that's consistent or maybe driven by or part of my argument that I don't believe I'm smart enough to define the difference between basic and applied research.
And I know I'm not smart enough to say I'm going to go in and do a piece of basic research and have it come out.
Unless I force it.
Unless I'm dishonest with the recertified statistics.
Or the inverse.
I may go in trying to build a specific widget and discover a new law.
I won't discover that new law unless I'm willing to.
If I just say I'm going to go in and do this widget, then at the best I can come out with is the widget.
That's right.
And I've missed that opportunity.
Unnecessary.
So, in my opinion, it's unnecessary to constrain the thought process or the administration definition.
From that point of view, there may be other reasons why it has to be carefully scrutinized.
Financial reasons, funding reasons, support reasons.

If for those other reasons that I've just mentioned, constraints are placed on this agency's ability by administrators, by offices, or by individuals whose philosophy differ with mine, who are in the positions of authority and responsibility,
to make the structure such that it inhibits it.
You can't stop it.
Stay consistent with my earlier.
You can make it difficult.
But if it is encouraged, this agency, or what it represents, whether it stays in this agency or not, but the interdisciplinary approach, the melting, the interaction,
Engineers can learn an awful lot from business people who can learn an awful lot from etc., etc., etc.
And where there's common purpose and goal, what's the way to do it?
The state needs it.
The nation needs it.
This window.
The window that began in the last decade will probably close in the next decade or two.
So it's a 20 or 30 year window that we're in.
The window's closed.
But we came to it, to move through it, a decade or so ago, although I don't think we even realized it.
We're running short of trained minds.
Not of minds with the ability, but of trained minds, those who have already developed the power
to participate and play in this high tech, whatever that means, game.
That is a society that's being driven by rapidly changing sources of jobs, rapidly changing talents, required to participate in making a living,

that's about the best way I can come at the definition of the high tech is that the demands on you to support the style of life that you want and do the things that you want to do are changing for you and you are being forced to learn how to use a computer whether you want to or not and if you choose not to
then we're coming back in this area to earlier in our conversation.
You may just have to take your fly rod and go fishing.
And you better be prepared to exercise that option, or you may just die.
So society is being driven in this window of time.
And by those kinds of rapidly changing factors,
And it's clear to me that the discipline of biology, natural sciences generally, is in an incredible percentage.
You're going to live to be 140, if you'd like to.
And the changes that's going to make in our lives.
But that is occurring in the same way.
So all of those technologies are going to come forth.
And that's part of
And I think I'm beginning to push you a little bit right now in the definition of high tech.
We might need to be going into very high tech for some of what I'm talking about here.
And I'm not sure if the window I'm speaking of now will have closed and we move into another one that will begin identifiable cycles and civilization.
But what's driving that, Debbie, is the world shrinking.
The marketplace.
We can walk out of here right now and be wherever you want to be.
Why do you put about 10 years ago?
I don't know.
Gut feeling.
Is there another one that you closed?
Because you've been...
The time period of the post-World War II period was such a period of growth that you closed it off.
I don't know the answer to that either.
I'm not a student of that.
I haven't studied society's evolution.
I've been locked up.
Well, technologically.
Yeah, well, I'm not a student of technology, but I'm not a student of the history of technology.
I'm sorry about that, by the way, because it's most useful.
I find myself now most intrigued by that and much more interested in it.
You know, when I was looking for Porter's Laws, who cared whose else laws there were?
But once you come up to a little clearer reality about your own, the...

the importance of how things happen still it become more interesting to me though not just as a matter out of curiosity but as a matter of trying to learn from that to control not yeah not just yeah and to control to the extent that we can learn from what has happened in order to manage
Maybe it's a better word.
But that's, in my mind, is still... Control is probably too strong, because I still think even in managing anything, it comes back to the research argument.
You want to manage it to a certain extent, but you don't want to try to manage it so that you don't give the project or the individuals in the project any kind of flexibility of their own.
I don't feel that smart, and I don't like to be around those who think they are, because I've already found it true.
What we need to do is to find generally where we think we can go, work towards that objective, but be reasonably flexible in meeting that objective so that if we find an incentive
that our preconceived ideas going in were off somewhat, if not totally wrong, then we've got the honesty to admit that and make a difference.
And pay the price, whatever it is.
Take the risk.
Don't worry about it.
Oh, I appreciate all your time.
Well, you know, all your questions are as good as I've had fun.
I'm enjoying it.
